newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Farm ministers could agree green money measures.
newsitem.headline: Farm ministers could agree green money measures.

text.p: European Union farm ministers could agree two agri-monetary proposals next week despite divisions between member states, a spokesman for the Dutch presidency told a news briefing on Thursday.

There is hope of agreement for a proposal fixing import taxes for all agricultural products at the monthly customs rate instead of the green rate used to calculate EU internal agricultural payments, the official said.
The Commission proposal aims to end the need to convert customs rates into green rates which it says is needlessly complicated.

A second proposal capping farmers compensation for loss of income due to national currency revaluations which cause reductions in green rate payments is opposed by Italy, Ireland and the United Kingdom.
"The Commission proposal would impose a limit from January 1 (1997) of seven percent of income lost in order to save the EU money.
"But, these three countries say that the limit is unfair because it did not apply to countries which were compensated before that date," a Council official said later.
"Of the two proposals the second presents the most difficulty but we are hopeful that both can be agreed next week," the Dutch official commented.
